title: AI in Medicine
content: Dr. Eric Topol shares how artificial intelligences and deep learning is currently impacting medicine and how it could transform the healthcare industry.

title: Patient Care
content: Dr. Eric Topol discusses how AI could revolutionize patient care, not only in terms of technological advancements, but also in restoring the patient-doctor relationship for better patient outcomes and experiences.

title: A breakthrough in heart monitoring
content: Eric was part of the group that realized that patients did not have to be monitored in hospital to get a 12-lead cardiogram. In fact, even to this day, people are having to wear a Holter monitor which was created in 1950. But we are getting away from that and Eric sees this as the entry point to a bright future in wireless heart monitoring. “20 years ago was kind of the entry point – where we just first dedicated wireless company card units – and it’s just where we’re going to build from to ultimately eradicate the need for most hospital rooms, which is a pretty big deal and it’s probably the most transformative aspect of where we’re headed because that’s the number one item for healthcare cost” – Eric Topol, M.D.

title: What is Vioxx?
content: A COX-2 selective nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) related to the nonselective NSAIDs , such as ibuprofen and naproxen. Instead of  Advil and Aleve and other nonsteroidals that it would replace, Vioxx would spare the stomach and would be a more potent pain reliever and anti-inflammatories.

title: The controversy
content: Topol and his colleagues published in 2001 was a meta-analysis of the 2000 Vioxx Gastrointestinal Outcomes Research Study (VIGOR), the 2000 Celecoxib Long-Term Arthritis Safety Study (CLASS), and 2 small trials with around 1000 subjects each. The VIGOR trial tested rofecoxib against another NSAID, naproxen, and found that, while the two groups had similar rates of CV-related deaths and overall mortality, Vioxx had a higher mortality rate. Merck attributed the comparatively high heart attack rates to an unproven protective effect of naproxen. Merck tried to intimidate Topol in order to get the paper withdrawn. There were other small studies, withheld by Merck, that showed excess heart attacks in those taking Vioxx. One in 50 absolute risk for hard mortality outcome. At the time, it was not clear who was at risk, but 80 million people took Vioxx.

title: Population comorbidity complications
content: Most people that have severe osteoarthritis are also having comorbidities that would put them at risk for heart attack (a ubiquitous disease). “You can’t single it out. It’s almost impossible. If you had assays to show the selectivity of the COX-2 inhibitor was prothrombotic, making a clot in a person, and that person then had a heart attack or stroke. But who had that? These were sudden events, and no one had a proof in that person that their clotting status changed from the drugs” – Eric Topol, M.D.

title: Why Eric has come to regret publishing the paper about Vioxx and how Merck avoided any big ramifications from their error
content: Eric says he regrets publishing the paper calling out Vioxx as Merck didn’t do anything (in terms of withdrawing the drug in direct response). Merck never really fessed up to the error and never had to pay out any money in lawsuits. “Nowadays, everybody talks about truths and fake and whatnot. But to me, then was the beginning of seeing that syndrome because here was truth, and it was just being basically turned into fake news by Merck, and they had gone years of marketing a drug, mass marketing a drug. You could not [have] turn on a TV set without seeing ads for Vioxx. And they never fessed up … Every single patient case that went to court, they basically prevailed eventually, whether it was the original case or the appeals, by this whole inability for proof in an individual patient. So they didn’t pay anything.”

title: Controversy over a drug
content: Eric recalls that it was a horrible time in his career. He received actually threats from people associated with Merck. And some people at the Cleveland Clinic, where Eric was working, were turning against him. The chairman of the board of the Cleveland Clinic [Malachi Mixon]  and the CEO of Merck [Raymond Gilmartin] were basically ganging up to suppress me and gag me and also to turn on me. So I had my own institution, I had Merck against me. It was a nightmare, I mean a veritable nightmare.

title: Founding of Scripps Translational Research Institute
content: Eric was recruited at Scripps Research in 2006 during which time Scripps Health was a separate entity. Eric came in as a  cardiologist at Scripps Clinic, but also to develop a new institute that was dedicated to translational research, particularly genomics. He came to Scripps to try to make human genomics and genetics center stage for the two Scripps Institutions. And he wanted to translate advancements as quickly as possible to patient care. Eric secured NIH grants for innovations in medicine.

title: AI and deep learning in medicine
content: Recognizing AI technology. What we’re talking about now is a specific subtype of AI, which got its birth just over 10 years ago, called deep learning, neural networks that allow for inputs. And they could be millions, billions of data points. It could be images, it could be speech, could be text. And then it goes these layers of artificial neurons, which are not very much like neurons. But nonetheless, they can distinguish features progressively as they go through this network. And then you get outputs. Technological advancements made in the field have been recognized by the A.M. Turing Award: Geoffrey Hinton and his colleagues received the award for engineering breakthroughs of deep neural network computing. Ongoing studies will demonstrate superiority of image definition accuracy, or as good as through machine. Deep learning accuracy can work synergistically with human doctors.

title: AI and Medicine
content: The thesis of Deep Medicine, Eric’s book, is that machine learning will free up time with patients that could restore the patient-doctor relationship back to where it was 40 years ago. There is a lot of promise and potential for AI but it has not [yet] been actualized. Clinical trials in colonoscopy utilize AI to improve the amount of overlooked polyps. A recent randomized trial utilized deep learning for polyp identification. Eric believes deep learning innovation will come from outside of big pharma. Google, Microsoft, Amazon all recognize this as the greatest opportunity for growth and also a noble mission of improving health. Startups, some governments like in China, the UK and other places are taking interest and investing in this space. The FDA has selectively approved algorithms for reading various types of scans, but such algorithms are widespread in China, for example.

title: AI Development Requirements
content: Medical field requires multimodal data collection and integration: varied types of inputs (e.g., vital signs, machine vision of patient facial recognition, different aspects of the patient, history, existing electronic record). Deep learning is still applied too narrowly (one modality). Development will head towards integrating data points; hybrid models to bring data together.

title: Consumer-Approved AI
content: An FDA consumer-approved algorithm is the Apple Watch for heart arrhythmia – a deep learning algorithm for atrial fibrillation. Algorithm was first developed by startup, AliveCor, and apple was a year later. A one-lead cardiogram reads for atrial fibrillation with a 90% or more accuracy level. Takes a matter of hours to learn a person well enough to make recommendations for a cardiogram but cannot diagnose anything else like ventricular rhythm (algorithms have not been validated yet). Eric uses a six-lead cardiogram with patients where the sensors are put on the leg. With every patient, Eric takes their pulse as well as the six-lead cardiogram. This allows Eric to see if they have an arrhythmia, and have any conduction system abnormalities. Patients could even do this test on their own at home at some point. Could perform a stress test from the phone and reveal heart rhythm abnormalities (precursor to arrhythmia. The results go to their phone and it creates a PDF which can be sent to your doctor.

title: AI and 12-lead cardiograms
content: Mayo clinic recently published papers on 12-lead cardiograms. As one report suggests, in addition to heart function, predicting atrial fibrillation, the application of artificial intelligence to the ECG may enable screening for dangerous potassium levels (hyperkalemia).

title: AI and continuous glucose monitoring
content: Peter discusses how AI could impact continuous glucose monitoring, suggesting that it would need to be coupled with other data. He dreams of being able to input desired glucose levels and variability and have the algorithm suggest what to eat. Eric believes we are getting closer to this.

title: AI and the gut microbiome
content: Peter is skeptical of the gut microbiome's impact on patient health, but acknowledges the potential for machine learning to improve research. A study has demonstrated an algorithm that accurately predicts personalized glycemic response to real-life meals using blood parameters, dietary habits, anthropometrics, physical activity, and gut microbiota.

title: The role of the gut microbiome in health
content: For one, he thinks that perhaps using the CGM and dietary logging would have been sufficient and that the gut microbiome may not have really “added” anything above those things. Furthermore, if you have realtime lactate you are estimating mitochondrial oxidation and therefore fuel partitioning. So, for example, the reason that right now Peter’s glucose is 94 and if he ate a bagel it would only go up to 104 is because he’s so glycogen depleted from not eating for 20 hours and having worked out. Conversely, after a big dinner which spiked your glucose to 120, and then it comes down to 94, if you were to eat that same bagel under those new conditions it would spike glucose much higher. A very important input into predicting that variation in how your blood glucose is going to respond to a particular meal is knowing glycogen stores and insulin sensitivity of the muscle and all these other things. Regarding the role of the gut, Peter is wanting to know: How many different macro phenotypes of gut biome are there that really matter? Eric’s response: He leans towards believing that each person’s unique individual response throughout their day is impacted by the gut. But… he understands the skeptical point of view on the gut and says: “it is early stages of research and the importance of studying the gut still needs to be validated”

title: The importance of machines and human doctors in medicine
content: Why machines combined with human doctors is superior to one without the other [1:32:15]. How machines can help our biggest blind spot. What is the biggest blind spot with human physicians? “I think the biggest blind spot is how poor we are in diagnosis.” Eric says that 40% of doctors who claim to know why a patient died are wrong after autopsy results. If a doctor is able to make a diagnosis for a patient in 5 minutes, they are 95% accurate, but if it takes them longer than that their accuracy falls to 24%. “We just are reflexive. We don’t reflectively go over anything. We don’t have time, we don’t assimilate all the data. We can’t because there’s so much . . . [we have to ] acknowledge that we can do far better but it can’t all be through human support. We need help.” – Eric Topol, M.D. Machines plus humans will always be better than just machine or just humans. Machines can vastly improve areas like radiology and critical care. But humans will always be better at the interaction with other humans and the connection/bond. Machines don’t have the context and deep, human nuanced issues that doctors can pick up. “They [machines] don’t have context. They’re not going to be able to truly understand all the nonverbal communication and the real issues of a person that are deep. And that’s where the humanity, we need to bring it back. I mean the essence of medicine is that, and it’s been lost. It’s become this big business.” – Eric Topol, M.D.

title: How AI and machines can help alleviate physician burnout
content: How AI and machines can reinstate medicine as an attractive career (and alleviate physician burnout) [1:37:00]. Physician burnout is an issue and is at its peak. Physicians have I become data clerks and they’re squeezed for time, and they can’t care for people when they don’t have time. Medicine as a career has become less and less attractive. Machines can help give doctor’s their time back. “The main thesis [of the book] is the gift of time. We can get that. But I think we have to restore medicine the way it was in order to attract the talent … and I think it’s doable, it’s not going to be easy, it’s going to require a lot of activism, which we haven’t had that much of, in medicine” – Eric Topol, M.D.

title: Why physicians should organize together
content: Why physicians should organize together. Physicians need to organize in order to restore a former medical care standard. There are a million physicians in the country (900,000 who are actually practicing). Eric published an article in The New Yorker on why doctors should organize to meet the challenges of modern medicine. An article published on the position of American physicians on firearms incited the reaction of the NRA.

title: AI implications for both doctors and patients
content: The machine story is not just about doctors relying more on machines getting support, it’s also about consumers, patients. And so when you get the outsourcing and the offloading, you start to see a pretty big… And then when you get rid of the hospital story and just have surveillance centers, remote monitoring, you start to see a very less need for expansion. So I don’t see we’re going to be a decline, but just a difference in the curves as they go forward over the next few decades” – Eric Topol, M.D.

title: We will need more doctors because of the aging population
content: At the same time, patients will be empowered with their own data so there will be less requirement for doctor-led diagnoses of the most common conditions. The medical specialities will shift away from a common-treatment focus.

title: Eric’s dream experiment
content: The point being is when a new person comes in and we want to prevent a condition or better treat it, and we have billions of other people to draw from, and we have these digital twins, if you will. Because today we learn from clinical trials and it’s really farcical in many respects…so my experiment would be just for that: You have pinpoint precision … and what treatment they got and what outcomes they got and how I can prevent their issue that they otherwise had. And so it would be to develop the ultimate learning health system” – Eric Topol, M.D.

title: Proof of concept
content: The data already exists but is fragmented. Once you develop it at some scale, you still have to prove that it’s helping people.
